column2: Of Masques And Triumphs
column3: Of Masques And Triumphs

column2: THESE things are but toys, to come amongst such serious observations. But yet, since princes will have such things, it is better they should be graced with elegancy, than daubed with cost.
column3: THESE things are but toys, to come amongst such serious observations. But yet, since princes will have such things, it is better they should be graced with elegancy, than daubed with cost.

column2: Dancing to song, is a thing of great state and pleasure.
column3: Dancing to song, is a thing of great state and pleasure.

column2: I understand it, that the song be in quire, placed aloft, and accompanied with some broken music; and the ditty fitted to the device.
column3: I understand it, that the song be in quire, placed aloft, and accompanied with some broken music; and the ditty fitted to the device.

column2: Acting in song, especially in dialogues, hath an extreme good grace; I say acting, not dancing (for that is a mean and vulgar thing); and the voices of the dialogue would be strong and manly (a base and a tenor; no treble); and the ditty high and tragical; not nice or dainty.
column3: Acting in song, especially in dialogues, hath an extreme good grace; I say acting, not dancing (for that is a mean and vulgar thing); and the voices of the dialogue would be strong and manly (a base and a tenor; no treble); and the ditty high and tragical; not nice or dainty.

column2: Several quires, placed one over against another, and taking the voice by catches, anthem-wise, give great pleasure.
column3: Several quires, placed one over against another, and taking the voice by catches, anthem wise, give great pleasure.

column2: Turning dances into figure, is a childish curiosity.
column3: Turning dances into figure, is a childish curiosity.

column2: And generally let it be noted, that those things which I here set down, are such as do naturally take the sense, and not respect petty wonderments. It is true, the alterations of scenes, so it be quietly and without noise, are things of great beauty and pleasure; for they feed and relieve the eye, before it be full of the same object.
column3: And generally let it be noted, that those things which I here set down, are such as do naturally take the sense, and not respect petty wonderments. It is true, the alterations of scenes, so it be quietly and without noise, are things of great beauty and pleasure; for they feed and relieve the eye, before it be full of the same object.

column2: Let the scenes abound with light, specially colored and varied; and let the masquers, or any other, that are to come down from the scene, have some motions upon the scene itself, before their coming down; for it draws the eye strangely, and makes it, with great pleasure, to desire to see, that it cannot perfectly discern.
column3: Let the scenes abound with light, specially colored and varied; and let the masquers, or any other, that are to come down from the scene, have some motions upon the scene itself, before their coming down; for it draws the eye strangely, and makes it, with great pleasure, to desire to see, that it cannot perfectly discern.

column2: Let the songs be loud and cheerful, and not chirpings or pulings.
column3: Let the songs be loud and cheerful, and not chirpings or pulings.

column2: Let the music likewise be sharp and loud, and well placed.
column3: Let the music likewise be sharp and loud, and well placed.

column2: The colors that show best by candle-light are white, carnation, and a kind of sea-water-green; and oes, or spangs, as they are of no great cost, so they are of most glory.
column3: The colors that show best by candle light are white, carnation, and a kind of sea water green; and o e s, or spangs, as they are of no great cost, so they are of most glory.

column2: As for rich embroidery, it is lost and not discerned.
column3: As for rich embroidery, it is lost and not discerned.

column2: Let the suits of the masquers be graceful, and such as become the person, when the vizors are off; not after examples of known attires; Turke, soldiers, mariners', and the like.
column3: Let the suits of the masquers be graceful, and such as become the person, when the vizors are off; not after examples of known attires; Turke, soldiers, mariners', and the like.

column2: Let anti-masques not be long; they have been commonly of fools, satyrs, baboons, wild-men, antics, beasts, sprites, witches, Ethiops, pigmies, turquets, nymphs, rustics, Cupids, statuas moving, and the like.
column3: Let anti masques not be long; they have been commonly of fools, satyrs, baboons, wild men, antics, beasts, sprites, witches, Ethiops, pigmies, turquets, nymphs, rustics, Cupids, statuas moving, and the like.

column2: As for angels, it is not comical enough, to put them in anti-masques; and anything that is hideous, as devils, giants, is on the other side as unfit.
column3: As for angels, it is not comical enough, to put them in anti masques; and anything that is hideous, as devils, giants, is on the other side as unfit.

column2: But chiefly, let the music of them be recreative, and with some strange changes.
column3: But chiefly, let the music of them be recreative, and with some strange changes.

column2: Some sweet odors suddenly coming forth, without any drops falling, are, in such a company as there is steam and heat, things of great pleasure and refreshment.
column3: Some sweet odors suddenly coming forth, without any drops falling, are, in such a company as there is steam and heat, things of great pleasure and refreshment.

column2: Double masques, one of men, another of ladies, addeth state and variety.
column3: Double masques, one of men, another of ladies, addeth state and variety.

column2: But all is nothing except the room be kept clear and neat.
column3: But all is nothing except the room be kept clear and neat.

column2: For justs, and tourneys, and barriers; the glories of them are chiefly in the chariots, wherein the challengers make their entry; especially if they be drawn with strange beasts: as lions, bears, camels, and the like; or in the devices of their entrance; or in the bravery of their liveries; or in the goodly furniture of their horses and armor.
column3: For justs, and tourneys, and barriers; the glories of them are chiefly in the chariots, wherein the challengers make their entry; especially if they be drawn with strange beasts: as lions, bears, camels, and the like; or in the devices of their entrance; or in the bravery of their liveries; or in the goodly furniture of their horses and armor.

column2: But enough of these toys.
column3: But enough of these toys.

column2: Of Nature In Men
column3: Of Nature In Men

column2: NATURE is often hidden; sometimes overcome; seldom extinguished.
column3: NATURE is often hidden; sometimes overcome; seldom extinguished.

column2: Force, maketh nature more violent in the return; doctrine and discourse, maketh nature less importune; but custom only doth alter and subdue nature.
column3: Force, maketh nature more violent in the return; doctrine and discourse, maketh nature less importune; but custom only doth alter and subdue nature.

column2: He that seeketh victory over his nature, let him not set himself too great, nor too small tasks; for the first will make him dejected by often failings; and the second will make him a small proceeder, though by often prevailings.
column3: He that seeketh victory over his nature, let him not set himself too great, nor too small tasks; for the first will make him dejected by often failings; and the second will make him a small proceeder, though by often prevailings.

column2: And at the first let him practise with helps, as swimmers do with bladders or rushes; but after a time let him practise with disadvantages, as dancers do with thick shoes.
column3: And at the first let him practise with helps, as swimmers do with bladders or rushes; but after a time let him practise with disadvantages, as dancers do with thick shoes.

column2: For it breeds great perfection, if the practice be harder than the use.
column3: For it breeds great perfection, if the practice be harder than the use.

column2: Where nature is mighty, and therefore the victory hard, the degrees had need be, first to stay and arrest nature in time; like to him that would say over the four and twenty letters when he was angry; then to go less in quantity; as if one should, in forbearing wine, come from drinking healths, to a draught at a meal; and lastly, to discontinue altogether.
column3: Where nature is mighty, and therefore the victory hard, the degrees had need be, first to stay and arrest nature in time; like to him that would say over the four and twenty letters when he was angry; then to go less in quantity; as if one should, in forbearing wine, come from drinking healths, to a draught at a meal; and lastly, to discontinue altogether.

column2: But if a man have the fortitude, and resolution, to enfranchise himself at once, that is the best:
column3: But if a man have the fortitude, and resolution, to enfranchise himself at once, that is the best:

column2: Optimus ille animi vindex laedentia pectus Vincula qui rupit, dedoluitque semel.
column3: Optimus ille animi vindex laedentia pectus Vincula qui rupit, dedoluitque semel.

column2: Neither is the ancient rule amiss, to bend nature, as a wand, to a contrary extreme, whereby to set it right, understanding it, where the contrary extreme is no vice.
column3: Neither is the ancient rule amiss, to bend nature, as a wand, to a contrary extreme, whereby to set it right, understanding it, where the contrary extreme is no vice.

column2: Let not a man force a habit upon himself, with a perpetual continuance, but with some intermission.
column3: Let not a man force a habit upon himself, with a perpetual continuance, but with some intermission.

column2: For both the pause reinforceth the new onset; and if a man that is not perfect, be ever in practice, he shall as well practise his errors, as his abilities, and induce one habit of both; and there is no means to help this, but by seasonable intermissions.
column3: For both the pause reinforceth the new onset; and if a man that is not perfect, be ever in practice, he shall as well practise his errors, as his abilities, and induce one habit of both; and there is no means to help this, but by seasonable intermissions.

column2: But let not a man trust his victory over his nature, too far; for nature will lay buried a great time, and yet revive, upon the occasion or temptation.
column3: But let not a man trust his victory over his nature, too far; for nature will lay buried a great time, and yet revive, upon the occasion or temptation.

column2: Like as it was with AEsop's damsel, turned from a cat to a woman, who sat very demurely at the board's end, till a mouse ran before her.
column3: Like as it was with AEsop's damsel, turned from a cat to a woman, who sat very demurely at the board's end, till a mouse ran before her.

column2: Therefore, let a man either avoid the occasion altogether; or put himself often to it, that he may be little moved with it.
column3: Therefore, let a man either avoid the occasion altogether; or put himself often to it, that he may be little moved with it.

column2: A man's nature is best perceived in privateness, for there is no affectation; in passion, for that putteth a man out of his precepts; and in a new case or experiment, for there custom leaveth him.
column3: A man's nature is best perceived in privateness, for there is no affectation; in passion, for that putteth a man out of his precepts; and in a new case or experiment, for there custom leaveth him.

column2: They are happy men, whose natures sort with their vocations; otherwise they may say, multum incola fuit anima mea; when they converse in those things, they do not affect.
column3: They are happy men, whose natures sort with their vocations; otherwise they may say, multum incola fuit anima mea; when they converse in those things, they do not affect.

column2: In studies, whatsoever a man commandeth upon himself, let him set hours for it; but whatsoever is agreeable to his nature, let him take no care for any set times; for his thoughts will fly to it, of themselves; so as the spaces of other business, or studies, will suffice.
column3: In studies, whatsoever a man commandeth upon himself, let him set hours for it; but whatsoever is agreeable to his nature, let him take no care for any set times; for his thoughts will fly to it, of themselves; so as the spaces of other business, or studies, will suffice.

column2: A man's nature, runs either to herbs or weeds; therefore let him seasonably water the one, and destroy the other.
column3: A man's nature, runs either to herbs or weeds; therefore let him seasonably water the one, and destroy the other.

column2: Of Custom And Education
column3: Of Custom And Education

column2: MEN'S thoughts, are much according to their inclination; their discourse and speeches, according to their learning and infused opinions; but their deeds, are after as they have been accustomed.
column3: MEN'S thoughts, are much according to their inclination; their discourse and speeches, according to their learning and infused opinions; but their deeds, are after as they have been accustomed.

column2: And therefore, as Machiavel well noteth (though in an evil-favored instance), there is no trusting to the force of nature, nor to the bravery of words, except it be corroborate by custom.
column3: And therefore, as Machiavel well noteth (though in an evil favored instance), there is no trusting to the force of nature, nor to the bravery of words, except it be corroborate by custom.

column2: His instance is, that for the achieving of a desperate conspiracy, a man should not rest upon the fierceness of any man's nature, or his resolute undertakings; but take such an one, as hath had his hands formerly in blood.
column3: His instance is, that for the achieving of a desperate conspiracy, a man should not rest upon the fierceness of any man's nature, or his resolute undertakings; but take such an one, as hath had his hands formerly in blood.

column2: But Machiavel knew not of a Friar Clement, nor a Ravillac, nor a Jaureguy, nor a Baltazar Gerard; yet his rule holdeth still, that nature, nor the engagement of words, are not so forcible, as custom.
column3: But Machiavel knew not of a Friar Clement, nor a Ravillac, nor a Jaureguy, nor a Baltazar Gerard; yet his rule holdeth still, that nature, nor the engagement of words, are not so forcible, as custom.

column2: Only superstition is now so well advanced, that men of the first blood, are as firm as butchers by occupation; and votary resolution, is made equipollent to custom, even in matter of blood.
column3: Only superstition is now so well advanced, that men of the first blood, are as firm as butchers by occupation; and votary resolution, is made equipollent to custom, even in matter of blood.

column2: In other things, the predominancy of custom is everywhere visible; insomuch as a man would wonder, to hear men profess, protest, engage, give great words, and then do, just as they have done before; as if they were dead images, and engines moved only by the wheels of custom.
column3: In other things, the predominancy of custom is everywhere visible; insomuch as a man would wonder, to hear men profess, protest, engage, give great words, and then do, just as they have done before; as if they were dead images, and engines moved only by the wheels of custom.

column2: We see also the reign or tyranny of custom, what it is.
column3: We see also the reign or tyranny of custom, what it is.

column2: The Indians (I mean the sect of their wise men) lay themselves quietly upon a stock of wood, and so sacrifice themselves by fire.
column3: The Indians (I mean the sect of their wise men) lay themselves quietly upon a stock of wood, and so sacrifice themselves by fire.

column2: Nay, the wives strive to be burned, with the corpses of their husbands.
column3: Nay, the wives strive to be burned, with the corpses of their husbands.

column2: The lads of Sparta, of ancient time, were wont to be scourged upon the altar of Diana, without so much as queching.
column3: The lads of Sparta, of ancient time, were wont to be scourged upon the altar of Diana, without so much as queching.

column2: I remember, in the beginning of Queen Elizabeth's time of England, an Irish rebel condemned, put up a petition to the deputy, that he might be hanged in a withe, and not in an halter; because it had been so used, with former rebels.
column3: I remember, in the beginning of Queen Elizabeth's time of England, an Irish rebel condemned, put up a petition to the deputy, that he might be hanged in a withe, and not in an halter; because it had been so used, with former rebels.

column2: There be monks in Russia, for penance, that will sit a whole night in a vessel of water, till they be engaged with hard ice.
column3: There be monks in Russia, for penance, that will sit a whole night in a vessel of water, till they be engaged with hard ice.

column2: Many examples may be put of the force of custom, both upon mind and body.
column3: Many examples may be put of the force of custom, both upon mind and body.

column2: Therefore, since custom is the principal magistrate of man's life, let men by all means endeavor, to obtain good customs. Certainly custom is most perfect, when it beginneth in young years: this we call education; which is, in effect, but an early custom.
column3: Therefore, since custom is the principal magistrate of man's life, let men by all means endeavor, to obtain good customs. Certainly custom is most perfect, when it beginneth in young years: this we call education; which is, in effect, but an early custom.

column2: So we see, in languages, the tongue is more pliant to all expressions and sounds, the joints are more supple, to all feats of activity and motions, in youth than afterwards.
column3: So we see, in languages, the tongue is more pliant to all expressions and sounds, the joints are more supple, to all feats of activity and motions, in youth than afterwards.

column2: For it is true, that late learners cannot so well take the ply; except it be in some minds, that have not suffered themselves to fix, but have kept themselves open, and prepared to receive continual amendment, which is exceeding rare.
column3: For it is true, that late learners cannot so well take the ply; except it be in some minds, that have not suffered themselves to fix, but have kept themselves open, and prepared to receive continual amendment, which is exceeding rare.

column2: But if the force of custom simple and separate, be great, the force of custom copulate and conjoined and collegiate, is far greater.
column3: But if the force of custom simple and separate, be great, the force of custom copulate and conjoined and collegiate, is far greater.

column2: For there example teacheth, company comforteth, emulation quickeneth, glory raiseth: so as in such places the force of custom is in his exaltation.
column3: For there example teacheth, company comforteth, emulation quickeneth, glory raiseth: so as in such places the force of custom is in his exaltation.

column2: Certainly the great multiplication of virtues upon human nature, resteth upon societies well ordained and disciplined.
column3: Certainly the great multiplication of virtues upon human nature, resteth upon societies well ordained and disciplined.

column2: For commonwealths, and good governments, do nourish virtue grown but do not much mend the deeds. But the misery is, that the most effectual means, are now applied to the ends, least to be desired.
column3: For commonwealths, and good governments, do nourish virtue grown but do not much mend the deeds. But the misery is, that the most effectual means, are now applied to the ends, least to be desired.

column2: Of Fortune
column3: Of Fortune

column2: IT CANNOT be denied, but outward accidents conduce much to fortune; favor, opportunity, death of others, occasion fitting virtue.
column3: IT CANNOT be denied, but outward accidents conduce much to fortune; favor, opportunity, death of others, occasion fitting virtue.

column2: But chiefly, the mould of a man's fortune is in his own hands.
column3: But chiefly, the mould of a man's fortune is in his own hands.

column2: Faber quisque fortunae suae, saith the poet.
column3: Faber quisque fortunae s u a e, saith the poet.

column2: And the most frequent of external causes is, that the folly of one man, is the fortune of another.
column3: And the most frequent of external causes is, that the folly of one man, is the fortune of another.

column2: For no man prospers so suddenly, as by others' errors.
column3: For no man prospers so suddenly, as by others' errors.

column2: Serpens nisi serpentem comederit non fit draco.
column3: Serpens nisi serpentem comederit non fit draco.

column2: Overt and apparent virtues, bring forth praise; but there be secret and hidden virtues, that bring forth fortune; certain deliveries of a man's self, which have no name.
column3: Overt and apparent virtues, bring forth praise; but there be secret and hidden virtues, that bring forth fortune; certain deliveries of a man's self, which have no name.

column2: The Spanish name, desemboltura, partly expresseth them; when there be not stonds nor restiveness in a man's nature; but that the wheels of his mind, keep way with the wheels of his fortune.
column3: The Spanish name, desemboltura, partly expresseth them; when there be not stonds nor restiveness in a man's nature; but that the wheels of his mind, keep way with the wheels of his fortune.

column2: For so Livy (after he had described Cato Major in these words, In illo viro tantum robur corporis et animi fuit, ut quocunque loco natus esset, fortunam sibi facturus videretur) falleth upon that, that he had versatile ingenium.
column3: For so Livy (after he had described Cato Major in these words, In illo viro tantum robur corporis et animi fuit, ut quocunque loco natus esset, fortunam sibi facturus videretur) falleth upon that, that he had versatile ingenium.

column2: Therefore if a man look sharply and attentively, he shall see Fortune: for though she be blind, yet she is not invisible.
column3: Therefore if a man look sharply and attentively, he shall see Fortune: for though she be blind, yet she is not invisible.

column2: The way of fortune, is like the Milken Way in the sky; which is a meeting or knot of a number of small stars; not seen asunder, but giving light together.
column3: The way of fortune, is like the Milken Way in the sky; which is a meeting or knot of a number of small stars; not seen asunder, but giving light together.

column2: So are there a number of little, and scarce discerned virtues, or rather faculties and customs, that make men fortunate.
column3: So are there a number of little, and scarce discerned virtues, or rather faculties and customs, that make men fortunate.

column2: The Italians note some of them, such as a man would little think.
column3: The Italians note some of them, such as a man would little think.

column2: When they speak of one that cannot do amiss, they will throw in, into his other conditions, that he hath Poco di matto.
column3: When they speak of one that cannot do amiss, they will throw in, into his other conditions, that he hath Poco di matto.

column2: And certainly there be not two more fortunate properties, than to have a little of the fool, and not too much of the honest.
column3: And certainly there be not two more fortunate properties, than to have a little of the fool, and not too much of the honest.

column2: Therefore extreme lovers of their country or masters, were never fortunate, neither can they be.
column3: Therefore extreme lovers of their country or masters, were never fortunate, neither can they be.

column2: For when a man placeth his thoughts without himself, he goeth not his own way. An hasty fortune maketh an enterpriser and remover (the French hath it better, entreprenant, or remuant); but the exercised fortune maketh the able man.
column3: For when a man placeth his thoughts without himself, he goeth not his own way. An hasty fortune maketh an enterpriser and remover (the French hath it better, entreprenant, or remuant); but the exercised fortune maketh the able man.

column2: Fortune is to be honored and respected, and it be but for her daughters, Confidence and Reputation.
column3: Fortune is to be honored and respected, and it be but for her daughters, Confidence and Reputation.

column2: For those two, Felicity breedeth; the first within a man's self, the latter in others towards him.
column3: For those two, Felicity breedeth; the first within a man's self, the latter in others towards him.

column2: All wise men, to decline the envy of their own virtues, use to ascribe them to Providence and Fortune; for so they may the better assume them: and, besides, it is greatness in a man, to be the care of the higher powers. So Caesar said to the pilot in the tempest, Caesarem portas, et fortunam ejus.
column3: All wise men, to decline the envy of their own virtues, use to ascribe them to Providence and Fortune; for so they may the better assume them: and, besides, it is greatness in a man, to be the care of the higher powers. So Caesar said to the pilot in the tempest, Caesarem portas, et fortunam ejus.

column2: So Sylla chose the name of Felix, and not of Magnus.
column3: So Sylla chose the name of Felix, and not of Magnus.

column2: And it hath been noted, that those who ascribe openly too much to their own wisdom and policy, end infortunate.
column3: And it hath been noted, that those who ascribe openly too much to their own wisdom and policy, end infortunate.

column2: It is written that Timotheus the Athenian, after he had, in the account he gave to the state of his government, often interlaced this speech, and in this, Fortune had no part, never prospered in anything, he undertook afterwards.
column3: It is written that Timotheus the Athenian, after he had, in the account he gave to the state of his government, often interlaced this speech, and in this, Fortune had no part, never prospered in anything, he undertook afterwards.

column2: Certainly there be, whose fortunes are like Homer's verses, that have a slide and easiness more than the verses of other poets; as Plutarch saith of Timoleon's fortune, in respect of that of Agesilaus or Epaminondas.
column3: Certainly there be, whose fortunes are like Homer's verses, that have a slide and easiness more than the verses of other poets; as Plutarch saith of Timoleon's fortune, in respect of that of Agesilaus or Epaminondas.

column2: And that this should be, no doubt it is much, in a man's self.
column3: And that this should be, no doubt it is much, in a man's self.

column2: Of Usury
column3: Of Usury

column2: MANY have made witty invectives against usury.
column3: MANY have made witty invectives against usury.

column2: They say that it is a pity, the devil should have God's part, which is the tithe.
column3: They say that it is a pity, the devil should have God's part, which is the tithe.

column2: That the usurer is the greatest Sabbath-breaker, because his plough goeth every Sunday.
column3: That the usurer is the greatest Sabbath breaker, because his plough goeth every Sunday.

column2: That the usurer is the drone, that Virgil speaketh of;
column3: That the usurer is the drone, that Virgil speaketh of;

column2: Ignavum fucos pecus a praesepibus arcent.
column3: Ignavum fucos pecus a praesepibus arcent.

column2: That the usurer breaketh the first law, that was made for mankind after the fall, which was, in sudore vultus tui comedes panem tuum; not, in sudore vultus alieni.
column3: That the usurer breaketh the first law, that was made for mankind after the fall, which was, in sudore vultus tui comedes panem tuum; not, in sudore vultus alieni.

column2: That usurers should have orange-tawny bonnets, because they do judaize.
column3: That usurers should have orange tawny bonnets, because they do judaize.

column2: That it is against nature for money to beget money; and the like.
column3: That it is against nature for money to beget money; and the like.

column2: I say this only, that usury is a concessum propter duritiem cordis; for since there must be borrowing and lending, and men are so hard of heart, as they will not lend freely, usury must be permitted.
column3: I say this only, that usury is a concessum propter duritiem cordis; for since there must be borrowing and lending, and men are so hard of heart, as they will not lend freely, usury must be permitted.

column2: Some others, have made suspicious and cunning propositions of banks, discovery of men's estates, and other inventions.
column3: Some others, have made suspicious and cunning propositions of banks, discovery of men's estates, and other inventions.

column2: But few have spoken of usury usefully.
column3: But few have spoken of usury usefully.

column2: It is good to set before us, the incommodities and commodities of usury, that the good, may be either weighed out or culled out; and warily to provide, that while we make forth to that which is better, we meet not with that which is worse.
column3: It is good to set before us, the incommodities and commodities of usury, that the good, may be either weighed out or culled out; and warily to provide, that while we make forth to that which is better, we meet not with that which is worse.
